title: Bank Seeks Legal Help Over Property ‎Rule Changes
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 24, 2015, 20:49 BST - UK Markets closed Bank Seeks Legal Help Over Property ‎Rule Changes By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 21 minutes ago View Photo 

Close Brothers (LSE: CBG.L - news ) , one of Britain's biggest challenger banks, has called in lawyers over proposed rule changes that the industry is warning could deepen the country's housebuilding crisis. 
Sky News has learnt that the financial services group has sought advice from Freshfields, one of the City's 'Magic Circle' firms, about the way that property development loans are to be treated by regulators. 
Under plans imposed by Europe, a reclassification of such loans would force banks to hold up to 50% more capital against them, which they warn would make them far less attractive to provide. 
Close Brothers' move‎ to seek a legal opinion about the reforms underlines the strength of feeling among UK lenders about the extent to which they feel penalised by regulatory changes. 
Other affected banks have also‎ sought legal advice about the changes and are in discussions with the banking supervisor, the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA), sources said. 
The sources added that the banks had been advised that housing development loans at historically modest LTV rates was "not particularly high-risk speculative lending and the words 'where appropriate' allow the PRA to use their discretion". 
"I wonder if the housing minister thinks lending at modest LTV [loan-to-value] to build houses is speculative high-risk lending," one bank executive said on Thursday. 
"Ultimately initiatives like Help To Buy won't succeed if there are no houses to buy." 
The warning comes amid growing political concern about the level of housebuilding activity in the UK. 
A source close to Close Brothers said that even if the risk-weights applied to housing development loans did increase substantially, the bank would continue to lend to the sector. 
"The bank has a long track record of lending prudently and profitably to the property development sector and it thinks the current risk-weighting of 100% is appropriate," the inside said. 
Close Brothers declined to comment. 
The issue is particularly sensitive because it comes as UK-based challenger banks argue that a new tax surcharge introduced by George Osborne has made it harder for them to compete.
